job_title: Case Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: This is a dynamic, supportive company that typically listens to their employees and frequently asks their opinions and input. They are flexible within reason and offer generous benefits.
cons: Sometimes the communication is not very good and policies can be inconsistent, resulting in confusion for clients and employees. Turnover rate is rather high.

job_title: Clinical Supervisor in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Salary and benefits are moderately decent---mostly in line with other community mental health agencies but still not as good as for profit.
cons: Executive and director leadership are misinformed, defensive, and unsupportive of staff. High rate of burn out, turn over, and gossip due to unreasonable pressure/expectations.

job_title: Clinical Supervisor in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: The people you work with
cons: Poor leadership at the highest levels

job_title: Psychiatrist in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Good coworkers very friendly and professional
cons: Absurd management wake up and listen and reduce the ridiculous number of administrative officers

job_title: Case Management in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great flexibility, great leaders who try .
cons: Management isn’t as organized and tends to move everywhere

review_title: It's ok place for new grads to learn.
job_title: Therapist in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: You will get lots of experience with different client populations, good training on documentation etc.
cons: Culture is not very supportive and focus is mainly on productivity versus quality of care.

review_title: Fairly easy job as far as medicine goes, decent pay
job_title: Physician Assistant in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
- Decent pay
- Full autonomy 
- Easy once you get a feel for the job
cons: - Sometimes difficult clientele (but such is the nature of psychiatry)

review_title: Does not value employees, no opportunity for growth
job_title: Authorization Specialist in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: The medical benefits are great, some of the teams are fantastic
cons: Most positions do not offer opportunity for advancement, middle management has been in place for SO many years there is no chance for change within departments. Pay is not competitive and employees with 1 or 20 years in the company are paid exactly the same. Good ole boy systems, sexism and racism are rampant throughout, employees are not valued and are treated as unskilled laborers rather than skilled educated professionals. High value placed on over-working and working un-paid.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Benefits, 401k, great coworkers, time off, holiday pay, mental health days
cons: Management can’t get it together and help the team figure it out. Short staffed beyond belief, overworked, inconsistent schedules for the “needs of the clinic”, no respect for life outside of work, will burn you out with no regrets and want more from you.

job_title: Therapist in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Good benefits and good opportunity for growth
cons: High caseloads, long hours, little admin time

review_title: Good place to cut your teeth
job_title: Clinician III in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Diversus is a good place to get your feet wet in the community mental health world. The benefits and PTO accrual and both generous and among the best I’ve seen in Colorado Springs.
cons: There tends to be a lot of burnout due to high caseload demands. There are also a lot of required team meetings which aren’t everyone’s thing. My job sometimes feels like admin competes against actual client care. There are also no yearly pay raises.

review_title: Leadership has changed, but the dysfunction remains
job_title: Support in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
- Great Benefits (medical, PTO, 401k matching)
- Supportive network of peers; this company is full of GOOD people in the lower levels 
- Quick response to COVID-19 and transitioning to work from home
cons:
- Micromanaging high-level leadership that has made little to no effort to get to really know the system or the people in it
- Executive leadership and VPs are demeaning to employees 
- Tons of money and time spent on a rebranding rather than really addressing issues that need to be addressed 
- Favoritism
- Consistent pressure to do more with less while we watch leaders spend money on senseless things

job_title: Medical Coder in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Flexible working hours start between 7:00 am and 9;00 am depending on position.
cons: Have to use sick time for appointments over a certain amount of time, won't allow make-up time unless done in same day.

review_title: Run don’t walk away from a job here
job_title: Clinician IV in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Coworkers are great and supportive
cons: So much money spent on rebranding the company during a pandemic and big hype that salaries were going to be increased. Lots of lies, the big “raise” was $60 a month. They don’t pay their employees enough to live in the county they work in. People are leaving left and right for higher paying jobs and lower case loads. Leadership doesn’t listen. They give “forced” self care time and think that “helps” moral is low.

job_title: Clinician in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Benefits are very affordable and relevant.
cons: They figure your salary that includes benefits.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: The company has great benefits.
cons: The client population is very challenging.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Very few now a days. They lost some major insurance stuff and it’s being taken out on employees. Benefits are still good I guess.
cons: Just did a bunch of layoffs, moving people from one site to another with minimal to no notice, low pay, no concern for employee safety, no communication between upper management and middle all the way down to regular employees, the second someone appears to be enjoying their job or taking a second to have a fun moment with a coworker, management assumes your lazy and not doing work. The worst thing, and this has been the same since I started a couple years ago... management preaches that they really want to hear from staff, but when a major change is afoot and staff have legitimate concerns about said changes, no one is willing to hear them. It’s gotten worse since they lost the Medicaid bid. CEO up and quit months ago (I think he saw the light) and still no replacement.

job_title: Case Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Opportunity to work with very knowledgable and dedicated staff. Great wellness program and benefits as well.
cons:
Managed care, or rather, managed "cost" rules everything here. Case loads are extremely large and productivity requirements result in burnout. Paperwork is also extremely heavy, and utilization management is bandaiding client problems temporarily and forcing clinicians to sacrifice their ethics and sound clinical expertise to get clients out the door shortly after they walked in.

Pay is also pretty cruddy for clinical staff and case management.

job_title: Outpatient Clinician in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Community Mental Health, pay, sick leave, 401k
cons:
Opportunistic workers focusing on self promotion rather than helping.  

Not enough social workers who are experts in community practices.  Executives don't realize the tremendous wealth of knowledge their direct service providers have.  They listen to a select few who in turn don't listen to others. Outsiders are hired for persoective yet ignoring the wealth of experience direct service providers have.  Administrative help is probably the biggest need to make sure therapists don't drown in paperwork.  Communications recognized as a problem. Yet communication consistently does not improve.

job_title: Clinician in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Good support from co-workers and good benefits such as PTO and retirement.  There are some very good clinical staff there.
cons: Little opportunities for advancement. Raises are non-existent and little input is given to clinical staff when changes are made. The last several years they have continued to make cuts that impact clinical which has led to high turnover. Caseloads are extremely high. Training opportunities outside of the organization are slim.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Good pay and good benefits. Most of the staff works as a team and the doctor is wonderful!
cons: Management doesn't care about staff. When an issue comes up the management doesn't want to deal with anything. There is no support or understanding about our real life outside of work and they want at least 45 days notice for a day off.

job_title: Trainer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great benefits, excellent paid time off.
cons:
Incredibly dysfunctional manager with no accountability from upper management even after numerous reports to Human Resources.  

Lack training or support.  Favoritism.  

No focus on development or career advancement.

Mission has been lost, leadership is non existent.  CEO has been asked to leave.  COO is acting as CEO.

Moral has tanked since losing the Medicaid contract, many staff have left as a result and the company is downsizing and laying off numerous staff.   Many remaining staff are fearful of losing their jobs and are being written up for unrealistic productivity goals.

job_title: Telecare
pros: They are innovative, think outside the box.  Managers have energy and passion for what they do and seem to care about quality client care and their employees.  Good training by managers in the Telecare program.  They offer remote work opportunities.  Liked my co-workers - very helpful during my training.
cons: Pay is low.  I was a part-time employee and benefits were not offered.

review_title: Disorganized, Lack of Support, Community Disservice
job_title: Nurse in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Decent pay for the amount of work required
cons: Medical aspect of the department is prehistoric and puts your nursing license in jeopardy everyday, for example paper MARs and charting are used.  The software is not adequate for medical purposes and likely does not meet meaningful use requirements.  Delineation of tasks are unclear. Despite promises of change nothing of importance changed. You are made to feel dispensable and it is clear you, as an employee will be first to be thrown under the bus when trouble arises. Most unfortunately, due to lack of employee moral, available staff and a hostile work environment patient care is adversely affected.

review_title: EHR trainer and Medical Records Coordinator
job_title: Medical Records Coordinator in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great benefits. Wellness initiatives. Coworkers are like family. The work environment is safe and pleasant. Whole-person wellness is encouraged and supported.
cons: Constant change in upper management. Inefficient communication. Morale is very low and there is very little incentive to stay after working several years. Bad behavior is enabled.

review_title: Mediocre position and pay in the mental health field
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great place to work. Supportive, friendly team members. This position provides the perfect opportunity to earn required LCSW experience, hours, and supervision.
cons: The frequency of client sessions are often compromised due to the overwhelming number of clients per caseload. Management is toxic and practices favoritism towards certain clinicians. At times, team members and supervisors can be very cliquey. Not compensated for overtime. Low pay.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Genuine opportunity to help clients and watch other people grow. Company seems to care about staff's personal development and provides a fair amount of training opportunities.
cons: It's difficult to advance through the company and there are not a lot of promotions. Raises come few and far between. Communication isn't always clear between each department.

review_title: Things are changing for the better
job_title: Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Career growth, helping in the community, development, accountability and time off.  I've had a lot of fun in the org.  Are all of my ideas incorporated, no, but they are listened to.
cons: Sometimes it takes a while to get things pushed through.  Administration can sometimes move slower but they are good about listening to ideas.

job_title: Center for Employment Opportunities Position in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: AspenPointe truely cares about its employees and works hard to ensure employee satisfaction.  Lots of autonomy allowed within the job and management is very open to new ideas and initiatives.
cons: No raises.  Unless you change positions to a management or higher level position your pay will remain the same.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: They really want you to succeed. They give you plenty of tools to do your job with excellence.
cons: The balance of quality care vs the bottom line could be shifting.

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: High individual responsibility and opportunities for professional development.
cons: Company needs to drastically expand to meet the volume of clients.

review_title: Great company to work for.  I have no real complaints from my time there.
job_title: Crisis Intake in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Co-workers and direct management were awesome to work with. Everybody was super helpful and nice.
cons: Not always having enough staff to cover shifts.

job_title: Clinician in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Benefits and Pto were good. Wellness perks were nice as well.
cons: Everything. Management constantly saying things like self care and client care, but then instructing you to do the opposite.

job_title: Case Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Good training, positive atmosphere, options for growth. Really good pay for the position.
cons: Rigid on documentation and productivity requirements.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great organization with very focused goals, Team/family atmosphere, very detailed processes, and wonderful HR team.
cons: no cons that I can think of

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Mental Health Days and Floating Holidays
cons: Management could use some revamping

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Vacation hours/ benefits. Some of the employees truly want to serve the community.
cons: Nepotism. Unqualified and untrained management.

job_title: Clinician in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Good team environment and great learning environment.
cons: High turn over of employees may affect moral.

review_title: Best place I have ever worked
job_title: Employee Training Coordinator in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Benefits Coworkers Culture Training my boss
cons: None none none none none

job_title: Director in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Senior Management works hard to make positive culture change
cons: Non Profit = Lower Pay

job_title: Patient Access in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great Benefits, Fair Pay, Friendly coworkers
cons: Leadership could use a lot more work

job_title: Case Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Helping clients over come barriers
cons: Filling a quota/sales job
